channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.

channel.itunes:summary: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast. http://www.npr.org/sections/science/

item.title: Why The Newly Proposed Sepsis Treatment Needs More Study
item.description: March 30, 2017 - The bodywide inflammation known as sepsis kills about 300,000 people in U.S. hospitals each year. Promising treatments have come and gone, warn skeptical doctors, who call for rigorous research.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 30, 2017 - The bodywide inflammation known as sepsis kills about 300,000 people in U.S. hospitals each year. Promising treatments have come and gone, warn skeptical doctors, who call for rigorous research. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/30/521918863/why-the-newly-proposed-sepsis-treatment-needs-more-study

item.title: Back From The Dead? Reported Sightings Fuel Hope For Return Of Tasmanian Tigers
item.description: March 30, 2017 - The last known Tasmanian tiger died more than eight decades ago. It has become the stuff of textbook sketches and yellowing photographs. But now, researchers are launching a new search.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 30, 2017 - The last known Tasmanian tiger died more than eight decades ago. It has become the stuff of textbook sketches and yellowing photographs. But now, researchers are launching a new search. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/30/522091683/back-from-the-dead-reported-sightings-fuel-hope-for-return-of-tasmanian-tigers

item.title: A Tiny Spot In Mouse Brains May Explain How Breathing Calms The Mind
item.description: March 30, 2017 - A cluster of neurons connects breathing and emotion centers in mouse brains, researchers say. If this turns out to be true in humans, it could explain how controlled breathing calms the mind.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 30, 2017 - A cluster of neurons connects breathing and emotion centers in mouse brains, researchers say. If this turns out to be true in humans, it could explain how controlled breathing calms the mind. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/30/522033368/a-tiny-spot-in-mouse-brains-may-explain-how-breathing-calms-the-mind

item.title: A Forgotten Shipwreck Imperils Washington's Oysters
item.description: March 30, 2017 - The sunken Hero, an Antarctic research vessel from the 1960s, is leaking oil into Willapa Bay, where more than half of the state's oysters are grown. And no one knows how to remove it.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 30, 2017 - The sunken Hero, an Antarctic research vessel from the 1960s, is leaking oil into Willapa Bay, where more than half of the state's oysters are grown. And no one knows how to remove it. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/03/30/521666711/a-forgotten-shipwreck-imperils-washingtons-oysters

item.title: A Surprising Explanation For Why Some Immigrants Excel In Science
item.description:
March 30, 2017 - It has to do with language learning, according to a new study from Duke University.
- http://www.npr.org/sections/ed/2017/03/30/521794961/a-surprising-explanation-for-why-some-immigrants-excel-in-science

item.title: EPA Says It Will Allow Continued Sale Of Controversial Pesticide
item.description: March 30, 2017 - The EPA is not going ahead with a proposed ban on a pesticide called chlorpyrifos, saying there's still scientific uncertainty over its safety. Environmental groups say it can harm young children.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 30, 2017 - The EPA is not going ahead with a proposed ban on a pesticide called chlorpyrifos, saying there's still scientific uncertainty over its safety. Environmental groups say it can harm young children. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/30/522015717/epa-says-it-will-allow-continued-sale-of-controversial-pesticide

item.title: Fewer Zika-Linked Birth Defects Than Expected
item.description: March 30, 2017 - Scientists expected a surge of severe birth defects in Brazil because of the Zika outbreak. But that didn't happen last year. Researchers are re-examining the link between Zika and birth defects.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 30, 2017 - Scientists expected a surge of severe birth defects in Brazil because of the Zika outbreak. But that didn't happen last year. Researchers are re-examining the link between Zika and birth defects. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/30/522015647/fewer-zika-linked-birth-defects-than-expected

item.title: Where Levees Fail In California, Nature Can Step In To Nurture Rivers
item.description: March 29, 2017 - After devastating floods, California is looking to spend billions on dams and levees. Some are calling for a new approach to flood control, one that mimics nature instead of trying to contain it.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 29, 2017 - After devastating floods, California is looking to spend billions on dams and levees. Some are calling for a new approach to flood control, one that mimics nature instead of trying to contain it. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/29/521939643/where-levees-fail-in-california-nature-can-step-in-to-nurture-rivers

item.title: SpaceX Reuses A Rocket To Launch A Satellite
item.description: March 29, 2017 - The private company sees Thursday's achievement as a step toward cheaper flights into deep space. The aerospace industry essentially has been throwing away its hefty and expensive rockets.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 29, 2017 - The private company sees Thursday's achievement as a step toward cheaper flights into deep space. The aerospace industry essentially has been throwing away its hefty and expensive rockets. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/29/521941656/launch-land-launch-spacex-tries-reusing-its-rocket

item.title: Fishermen Catch 50-Pound Carp In The Middle Of Los Angeles
item.description: March 29, 2017 - MacArthur Park in Los Angeles is not the most picturesque location, but it is where the California Ghetto Carping Club caught a 50 pound carp this week.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 29, 2017 - MacArthur Park in Los Angeles is not the most picturesque location, but it is where the California Ghetto Carping Club caught a 50 pound carp this week. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/29/521954082/fishermen-catch-50-pound-carp-in-the-middle-of-los-angeles

item.title: EPA Decides Not To Ban A Pesticide, Despite Its Own Evidence Of Risk
item.description: March 29, 2017 - New EPA administrator Scott Pruitt has decided not to ban chlorpyrifos, a pesticide widely used on produce. That's despite evidence previously compiled by EPA showing it could pose risks to consumers.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 29, 2017 - New EPA administrator Scott Pruitt has decided not to ban chlorpyrifos, a pesticide widely used on produce. That's despite evidence previously compiled by EPA showing it could pose risks to consumers. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/03/29/521898976/will-the-epa-reject-a-pesticide-or-its-own-scientific-evidence

item.title: HPV Vaccine Could Protect More People With Fewer Doses, Doctors Insist
item.description: March 29, 2017 - In the U.S., there are about 39,000 cancers associated with the human papillomavirus each year. Doctors say the new HPV vaccine may help reduce the number of cases.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 29, 2017 - In the U.S., there are about 39,000 cancers associated with the human papillomavirus each year. Doctors say the new HPV vaccine may help reduce the number of cases. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/03/29/521711879/hpv-vaccine-could-protect-more-people-with-fewer-doses-doctors-insist

item.title: Passengers Take Flight To View Southern Lights
item.description: March 29, 2017 - The Aurora Australis is a display of neon green lights that dance across the southern skies. A plane took off from New Zealand to get a special view.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 29, 2017 - The Aurora Australis is a display of neon green lights that dance across the southern skies. A plane took off from New Zealand to get a special view. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/29/521884266/passengers-take-flight-to-view-southern-lights

item.title: Measuring The Impact Of Rolling Back Environmental Regulations
item.description: March 29, 2017 - President Trump's environmental order proposes rolling back regulations. David Greene speaks with John Larsen of the Rhodium Group about the impact those rollbacks could have on emissions levels.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 29, 2017 - President Trump's environmental order proposes rolling back regulations. David Greene speaks with John Larsen of the Rhodium Group about the impact those rollbacks could have on emissions levels. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/29/521884350/measuring-the-impact-of-rolling-back-environmental-regulations

item.title: Scientists Who Want To Study Climate Engineering Shun Trump
item.description: March 29, 2017 - The controversial study of climate engineering — aka deliberately messing with Earth's temperature — was finally starting to regain a measure of respectability. And then came President Trump.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: March 29, 2017 - The controversial study of climate engineering — aka deliberately messing with Earth's temperature — was finally starting to regain a measure of respectability. And then came President Trump. http://www.npr.org/2017/03/29/521780927/scientists-who-want-to-study-climate-engineering-shun-trump
